Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Parallel Dynamic Meshing Techniques for Simulation-Assisted Medical Interventions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigators will research and develop parallel dynamic meshing algorithms, theory, and software for use in the patient-specific design of inferior vena cava (IVC) filters for improved treatment of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). This life-threatening disease results when blood clots form in a deep vein; DVT effects over 2,000,000 people in the U.S. each year. A mechanical filter is often placed in the IVC in order to trap a moving blood clot before it reaches the heart. A typical doctor uses only one or two types of filters when treating his patients rather than selecting the most appropriate IVC filter for his patient's condition. Current computational simulations of blood clot entrapment by IVC filters are of low accuracy. Hence, techniques to generate accurate meshes of the IVC and surrounding veins, IVC filter, and blood clots for use in such simulations will be developed.

The investigators will develop novel, parallel dynamic meshing techniques to generate accurate meshes of the IVC and surrounding veins, IVC filter, and blood clots. The investigators will develop parallel mesh warping algorithms and muticore software for updating the meshes in response to patient-specific deformations. Parallel geometric and topological mesh optimization methods in order to improve the quality of the meshes will be developed. The algorithms will be encapsulated in the form of a parallel dynamic meshing toolkit for simulation-assisted medical interventions. In addition, the researchers will develop a theoretical framework for dynamic meshing for improved quantitative understanding of deformations. Educational activities at the college- and pre-college level will be designed to build pathways for women and underrepresented students to pursue computational science.

Institution.Name: University of Kansas Center for Research Inc
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF KANSAS CENTER FOR RESEARCH, INC.

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Kansas Center for Research Inc

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Meshes refer to the discretization of a geometry which serves as an approximation of the geometry for use with geometry-based analysis techniques.  The surface and volume of the geometry are typically discretized into shapes, e.g., triangles and quadrilaterals in 2D, and tetrahedra and cubes in 3D.   

There are numerous applications for which the geometric domain of interest deforms as a function of time.  For example, the human heart beats in order to pump oxygen-rich blood throughout the body, and materials deposited in layers self-fold and self-stretch in order to build 3D printed objects.  For such applications, the mesh must be updated at each time step in response to the deforming domain boundary in order for the mesh to remain a valid approximation of the geometry.  The problem of maintaining a mesh for a geometric domain whose shape is changing is called dynamic mesh generation.  One approach for updating the mesh in order to account for this change in shape is to warp it, or transfer it, from the initial domain onto the final domain.  Dynamic meshes must be of sufficient quality for use in geometry-based analysis techniques.  Geometric and topological operations, such as movement of the mesh nodes to new locations and swapping of mesh edges, can be applied in order to improve the element shapes and hence the mesh quality.  Untangling of a mesh can be performed in the event that the mesh elements change their orientation during computer simulations involving significant motion relative to the size and shape of the elements.   

In this project, we developed computer algorithms which generate dynamic meshes for use in computer simulations involving motion.  The corresponding software can be run on one computer or in a distributed manner on many computers in a high performance computing cluster.  In particular, we developed computer algorithms for mesh warping, mesh quality improvement, and mesh untangling.  The algorithms have been incorporated into serial and parallel dynamic meshing software toolkits which can be used by computational scientists and the general public. 

We used the resulting computer software to generate patient-specific meshes for use in simulation-assisted medical interventions.  Medical interventions that can be assisted by computer simulations include implantation of medical devices as well as surgeries.  In this project, we performed computer simulations of the prevention of pulmonary embolism through the implantation of a medical device (i.e., an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter) which traps blood clots.  Dynamic meshes were required in order to accurately capture the many shape changes in the patient’s veins and blood clots due to respiration and transport, respectively, and in the medical device due to implantation.  Through our simulations, we demonstrated that the performance of a given IVC is dependent on the patient’s anatomy. 

We also performed computer simulations of the onset and treatment of hydrocephalus, a disease involving excess cerebrospinal fluid on the brain.  Patient-specific meshes of the brain were generated in order to capture changes to it based on the excess fluid (during onset of the disease) and the response to a shunt, i.e., a mechanical device which is used to drain the excess fluid (during treatment).  Our computer software was successfully used to track the evolution of the brain ventricles in hydrocephalic patients. 

In regards to education, we developed educational materials for two new courses to be added to the computational science curriculum at the University of Kansas.  Computer Modeling, Simulation, and Visualization is a graduate-level course and is also open to well-prepared undergraduate students.  The course covers the mathematical and computational modeling of physical or biological phenomena, mathematical algorithms and computer software which is used to perform computer simulations of the phenomena, and scientific visualization methods and computer software which is used to visualize the results of the computer simulation. 

We have also developed a graduate-level course entitled Meshing Techniques.  The course covers the mathematics of meshing, meshing algorithms (e.g., for mesh generation, mesh quality improvement, mesh untangling, and other areas of meshing) and software, and applications of meshing. 

We have organized several outreach activities focused at the college- and pre-college level designed to build pathways for women and underrepresented minorities.  One highlight was a workshop we organized for middle school students, high school students, and undergraduate students to learn about computational biomedical science via outreach presentations and age-appropriate activities.  Students at the undergraduate level also learned about scientific visualization and biomedical engineering.  Numerous students who attended the workshops were female or from underrepresented minority groups.    

These research, education, and outreach activities were conducted at Penn State, Mississippi State, and the University of Kansas by the research team and our collaborators from various institutions in the United States and abroad.

 


Last Modified: 05/31/2017
Modified by: Suzanne M Shontz
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Meshes refer to the discretization of a geometry which serves as an approximation of the geometry for use with geometry-based analysis techniques. The surface and volume of the geometry are typically discretized into shapes, e.g., triangles and quadrilaterals in 2D, and tetrahedra and cubes in 3D. There are numerous applications for which the geometric domain of interest deforms as a function of time. For example, the human heart beats in order to pump oxygen-rich blood throughout the body, and materials deposited in layers self-fold and self-stretch in order to build 3D printed objects. For such applications, the mesh must be updated at each time step in response to the deforming domain boundary in order for the mesh to remain a valid approximation of the geometry. The problem of maintaining a mesh for a geometric domain whose shape is changing is called dynamic mesh generation. One approach for updating the mesh in order to account for this change in shape is to warp it, or transfer it, from the initial domain onto the final domain. Dynamic meshes must be of sufficient quality for use in geometry-based analysis techniques. Geometric and topological operations, such as movement of the mesh nodes to new locations and swapping of mesh edges, can be applied in order to improve the element shapes and hence the mesh quality. Untangling of a mesh can be performed in the event that the mesh elements change their orientation during computer simulations involving significant motion relative to the size and shape of the elements. In this project, we developed computer algorithms which generate dynamic meshes for use in computer simulations involving motion. The corresponding software can be run on one computer or in a distributed manner on many computers in a high performance computing cluster. In particular, we developed computer algorithms for mesh warping, mesh quality improvement, and mesh untangling. The algorithms have been incorporated into serial and parallel dynamic meshing software toolkits which can be used by computational scientists and the general public. We used the resulting computer software to generate patient-specific meshes for use in simulation-assisted medical interventions. Medical interventions that can be assisted by computer simulations include implantation of medical devices as well as surgeries. In this project, we performed computer simulations of the prevention of pulmonary embolism through the implantation of a medical device (i.e., an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter) which traps blood clots. Dynamic meshes were required in order to accurately capture the many shape changes in the patient?s veins and blood clots due to respiration and transport, respectively, and in the medical device due to implantation. Through our simulations, we demonstrated that the performance of a given IVC is dependent on the patient?s anatomy. We also performed computer simulations of the onset and treatment of hydrocephalus, a disease involving excess cerebrospinal fluid on the brain. Patient-specific meshes of the brain were generated in order to capture changes to it based on the excess fluid (during onset of the disease) and the response to a shunt, i.e., a mechanical device which is used to drain the excess fluid (during treatment). Our computer software was successfully used to track the evolution of the brain ventricles in hydrocephalic patients. In regards to education, we developed educational materials for two new courses to be added to the computational science curriculum at the University of Kansas. Computer Modeling, Simulation, and Visualization is a graduate-level course and is also open to well-prepared undergraduate students. The course covers the mathematical and computational modeling of physical or biological phenomena, mathematical algorithms and computer software which is used to perform computer simulations of the phenomena, and scientific visualization methods and computer software which is used to visualize the results of the computer simulation. We have also developed a graduate-level course entitled Meshing Techniques. The course covers the mathematics of meshing, meshing algorithms (e.g., for mesh generation, mesh quality improvement, mesh untangling, and other areas of meshing) and software, and applications of meshing. We have organized several outreach activities focused at the college- and pre-college level designed to build pathways for women and underrepresented minorities. One highlight was a workshop we organized for middle school students, high school students, and undergraduate students to learn about computational biomedical science via outreach presentations and age-appropriate activities. Students at the undergraduate level also learned about scientific visualization and biomedical engineering. Numerous students who attended the workshops were female or from underrepresented minority groups. These research, education, and outreach activities were conducted at Penn State, Mississippi State, and the University of Kansas by the research team and our collaborators from various institutions in the United States and abroad.
